column1: So the poor miller's daughter sat down. She hadn't the least idea of how to spin straw into gold
column2: and at last she began to cry. Suddenly the door opened
column3: and in stepped a tiny little man who said: "Good evening
column4: Miss Miller-maid; why are you crying so bitterly?""Oh!" answered the girl
column5: "I have to spin straw into gold
column6: and haven't the slightest notion how it's done." "What will you give me if I spin it for you?" asked the manikin."My necklace
column7: replied the girl.The little man took the necklace, sat down at the wheel, and whir, whir, whir, round it went until morning, when all the straw was spun away, and all the bobbins were full of gold.As soon as the sun rose, the King came, and when he saw the gold he was astonished and delighted, but he wanted more of the precious metal. He had the miller's daughter put into another room, much bigger than the first and full of straw, and bade her, if she valued her life, spin it all into gold before morning.
